column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=A 64 sample segment of EGM waveform (Raw EGM at a sampling rate of 250 Hz (8 bit A/D) is shown in the upper left hand corner of FIG. 6 at 320.
#Text=This is an acute human far-field EGM measured between the RV coil and the enclosure of a device as illustrated in FIG. 1.

#Text=The 64 sample segment of data (254 milliseconds) was extracted from a continuous multi-channel recording using the technique of centering a morphology window around the bipolar sensed ventricular depolarization, as described in the above-cited Mader et al. patent.

#Text=Below the Raw EGM segment on at 320 are wavelet representations of the Raw EGM using the largest wavelet coefficient at 322, the 10 largest wavelet coefficients at 324 and all 64 wavelet coefficients at 326 .

#Text=The thin lines 330 represent the wavelet(s) and associated amplitude(s), and the overlaid bold lines 332 trace the reconstructed waveforms, generated by performing the inverse DWT on the largest amplitude, the 10 largest amplitude and all 64 wavelet coefficients, respectively.
#Text=The fidelity of the reconstructed waveform improves as more wavelets are used for the reconstruction.
#Text=When all 64 wavelets are used, the original waveform is reconstructed accurately.

#Text=The right hand side of FIG. 6 at 328 shows the six different time-scaled wavelets and the corresponding coefficient numbers c.sub.i as defined in FIG. 4 that form the shorthand notation for each wavelet coefficient and associated wavelet.
#Text=The widest wavelet function in the upper right of FIG. 6 has two coefficient numbers (0 and 1) since two shifts of this wavelet function are needed to cover all 64 samples.
#Text=Similarly, the narrowest wavelet (the "mother wavelet") has 32 coefficient numbers (32 through 63) corresponding to the 32 shifts needed to cover all 64 samples.
#Text=The Haar wavelet coefficients indicate how fast an average of a function changes at different scales.

#Text=For example, coefficients (32-63) are just differences of the function values in consecutive points, coefficients (16-31) are differences of function average values over two points multiplied by two, coefficients (8-15) are differences of function average values over four points multiplied by four, and so on.
#Text=The other information coded in the wavelet coefficients is exactly where the signal changes occur at each scale.

#Text=For example, if a signal has a sharp peak in the center, only a few wavelet coefficients will be large, namely the ones that describe changes in signal at very fine scales and associated with the corresponding wavelets localized in the center of the analyzed signal.

#Text=Furthermore, if the signal has a significant slow component, then in addition to few fine scale coefficients, a few larger scale coefficients will be significant in the wavelet expansion, and so on.
#Text=Lower absolute value coefficients are less relevant, and in the approach taken by the present invention, will be filtered out and will not take part in further computation.

#Text=In addition to filtering based on the amplitude of the wavelet coefficients described above, it may be desired to filter out wavelet coefficients representing certain scales where unimportant signal information is represented.
#Text=For example, the wavelet coefficients representing the widest wavelets may be set to zero to eliminate the contributions of the widest scale attributes of the signal.
#Text=Other sets of wavelet coefficients representing a particular scale may be zeroed out to eliminate the contributions, depending on the application desired.

#Text=In one preferred embodiment of this invention, the 48 point Haar wavelet transform described above is used, and the three highest numbered wavelet coefficients, (corresponding to the three widest wavelets) which do not provide significant signal discrimination, are set to 0 and thereby filtered out.
#Text=Alternatives to this method may utilize all wavelet coefficients, or may filter out different sets corresponding to different scales in order to optimize discrimination performance.
#Text=FIG. 7 illustrates how the DWT is used to form a waveform description for purposes of EGM waveform discrimination according to the first embodiment of the present invention.
#Text=A DWT using the Haar function is computed based on the raw EGM input.

#Text=The N most significant wavelets (preferably selected from the wavelets remaining after filtering by setting certain wavelet coefficients equal to zero as described above) are selected (N=10 in the example presented).
#Text=This is done in the present embodiment by simply selecting the N largest absolute amplitude wavelet coefficients (corresponding to largest contribution).

#Text=The decision to use 10 wavelets in this embodiment employing a 64 sample waveform was based on early analysis that indicated that fewer than 10 coefficients was not adequate to discriminate some waveforms, and using more than 10 coefficients did not significantly improve performance.

#Text=In a more general case, the number of coefficients employed may be determined alternatively, for example by including only coefficients which have absolute amplitudes which exceed a predetermined percentage of the maximum absolute amplitude of all coefficients.

#Text=In such an embodiment, the number of coefficients employed to form the waveform description of the template waveform could likewise be employed to subsequently form the waveform description unknown waveforms.

#Text=Selection of only the wavelet coefficients having the largest amplitude coefficients provides an effective form of filtration and de-noising of the transformed waveform, with a minimum of computational complexity.

#Text=The graph at the lower left of FIG. 7 at 340 shows the waveform reconstructed (thick line 342) by selecting the 10 largest absolute amplitude wavelets (thin lines 344), and performing an inverse DWT.
#Text=Also shown are the coefficient numbers and amplitudes for the 10 largest DWT coefficients, and the ranked ordered coefficient numbers (ranked by absolute amplitude).
#Text=The EGM description is shown in the rightmost column at 346 and is given by the wavelet coefficient numbers, ordered by rank amplitude.
